items.synopsis: Many of us are now dressed head to toe in plastic thanks to the invention of cheap and durable textiles like polyester. But the extent of the environmental impact from these garments might surprise you — we've tracked the life cycle of a polyester top from an oil field, through to when you chuck it in the bin.

title.children: Gym clothes, party dresses, work clothes — most of us are wearing plastic. What goes into making a polyester T-shirt?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: At least one person has been killed in a school shooting in the US state of North Carolina. The University of North Carolina says a faculty member has been shot dead in a campus building in Chapel Hill. A suspect has been arrested, but a motive is not yet known and the weapon has not been found. Students and faculty at the campus had barricaded themselves in dorm rooms, offices and classrooms for hours until a lockdown was lifted.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Students barricade themselves in dorms, classrooms amid US university shooting

children.content: At least one person has been killed in a school shooting in the US state of North Carolina.
The University of North Carolina says a faculty member has been shot dead in a campus building in Chapel Hill.
A suspect has been arrested, but a motive is not yet known and the weapon has not been found.
Students and faculty at the campus had barricaded themselves in dorm rooms, offices and classrooms for hours until a lockdown was lifted.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal Senate inquiry into Australia's preparedness to host international sporting events will travel to regional Victoria today. On what will be the second day of the public hearing, witnesses from cities which were to host the ill-fated 2026 Commonwealth Games will give evidence in Bendigo. Athletics Australia director Steve Moneghetti is among sports executives expected to provide a testimony. Yesterday, the inquiry heard from Gold Coast Mayor Tom Tate, who flagged Queensland as a potential host for the 2026 Games.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Commonwealth Games inquiry to visit Victoria

children.content: The federal Senate inquiry into Australia's preparedness to host international sporting events will travel to regional Victoria today.
On what will be the second day of the public hearing, witnesses from cities which were to host the ill-fated 2026 Commonwealth Games will give evidence in Bendigo.
Athletics Australia director Steve Moneghetti is among sports executives expected to provide a testimony.
Yesterday, the inquiry heard from Gold Coast Mayor Tom Tate, who flagged Queensland as a potential host for the 2026 Games.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A magnitude 7.1 earthquake has struck the Bali Sea region of Indonesia in the early hours of the morning. Its epicentre was 201 kilometres north of the city of Mataram on the island of Lombok — and 518 kilometres below the surface. No tsunami warning has been issued for the region. The quake was felt in Bali, with many people there taking to social media to say they were woken by the shaking.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Earthquake strikes near Indonesia

children.content: A magnitude 7.1 earthquake has struck the Bali Sea region of Indonesia in the early hours of the morning.
Its epicentre was 201 kilometres north of the city of Mataram on the island of Lombok — and 518 kilometres below the surface.
No tsunami warning has been issued for the region.
The quake was felt in Bali, with many people there taking to social media to say they were woken by the shaking.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As a pay dispute at Chevron's LNG facilities remains unresolved, the Offshore Alliance of unions says members are planning escalating industrial action from September 7. In a statement to the ABC, a Chevron spokesperson says the comapny's received notices of protected action at its Gorgon and Wheatstone facilities, off the coast of Western Australia. "While we don't believe that industrial action is necessary for agreement to be reached, we recognise employees have the right to take protected industrial action and we will continue to take steps to maintain safe and reliable operations in the event of disruption at our facilities," a Chevron Australia spokesperson said. "We will also continue to work through the bargaining process as we seek outcomes that are in the interests of both employees and the company." In a Facebook post, the Offshore Alliance said its members "won't be intimidated" and slammed the bargaining process. According to Reuters, European natural gas prices surged overnight following the news of the stoppages late yesterday, as Gorgon and Wheatstone account for more than 5 per cent of global LNG production capacity. Last week, strikes were averted at Woodside's offshore LNG projects after a pay deal was struck.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chevron responds as unions plan work stoppages

children.content: As a pay dispute at Chevron's LNG facilities remains unresolved, the Offshore Alliance of unions says members are planning escalating industrial action from September 7.
In a statement to the ABC, a Chevron spokesperson says the comapny's received notices of protected action at its Gorgon and Wheatstone facilities, off the coast of Western Australia.

"While we don't believe that industrial action is necessary for agreement to be reached, we recognise employees have the right to take protected industrial action and we will continue to take steps to maintain safe and reliable operations in the event of disruption at our facilities," a Chevron Australia spokesperson said.
"We will also continue to work through the bargaining process as we seek outcomes that are in the interests of both employees and the company."
In a Facebook post, the Offshore Alliance said its members "won't be intimidated" and slammed the bargaining process.

According to Reuters, European natural gas prices surged overnight following the news of the stoppages late yesterday, as Gorgon and Wheatstone account for more than 5 per cent of global LNG production capacity.
Last week, strikes were averted at Woodside's offshore LNG projects after a pay deal was struck.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The boss of Virgin Australia Jayne Hrdlicka says allowing Qatar Airways to add more capacity would help lower airfares for customers. Virgin, which has a partnership with Qatar, has been critical of the federal government's decision to block extra flights into Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane by the international carrier. Qantas boss Alan Joyce was questioned by senators yesterday over the airline's lobbying of the government on the issue and why it was in the national interest, as politicians and Mr Joyce have argued. Speaking on RN Breakfast this morning, Ms Hrdlicka disputed the national interest argument. "I would just encourage the government to step back and say, let's get all the facts on the table and understand what's actually in the national interest. "There's over $500 million in economic interest at stake here for the tourism industry — that's a lot of jobs." Ms Hrdlicka wants the government to reopen the decision and says Virgin has sought meetings with the prime minister but hasn't heard back. "The statistics say that two-thirds of the seats that were flying in and out of Australia pre-COVID are back and a third of those seats are not back yet. "So if we get those seats back, airfares will be as low as they possibly can be." Yesterday, the Qantas chief executive argued that capacity was already increasing, with additional flights added by Singapore Airlines and China Southern. You can read a full recap of Mr Joyce's Senate grilling from business reporter Kate Ainsworth here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Virgin boss: government should rethink Qatar decision

featuredLink.title: Qantas admits to holding at least $470 million in unused flight credits from customers

this morning, Ms Hrdlicka disputed the national interest argument.
"I would just encourage the government to step back and say, let's get all the facts on the table and understand what's actually in the national interest.

Ms Hrdlicka wants the government to reopen the decision and says Virgin has sought meetings with the prime minister but hasn't heard back.
"The statistics say that two-thirds of the seats that were flying in and out of Australia pre-COVID are back and a third of those seats are not back yet.
"So if we get those seats back, airfares will be as low as they possibly can be."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Workers at Chevron's Australian liquefied natural gas operations are planning "rolling stoppages, bans and limitations" from September 7, as pay negotiations continue. In a social media post, the Offshore Alliance, which is a partnership between the Australian Workers' Union and the Maritime Union of Australia, said its lawyers had served Chevron with a formal notice of protected industrial action. The Alliance slammed Chevron's bargaining efforts and said the actions would escalate each week until bargaining claims are agreed to. "While we don't believe that industrial action is necessary for agreement to be reached, we recognise employees have the right to take protected industrial action," Chevron said in a statement to Reuters. "We will continue to take steps to maintain safe and reliable operations in the event of disruption at our facilities."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chevron LNG workers plan industrial action

children.content: Workers at Chevron's Australian liquefied natural gas operations are planning "rolling stoppages, bans and limitations" from September 7, as pay negotiations continue.

In a social media post, the Offshore Alliance, which is a partnership between the Australian Workers' Union and the Maritime Union of Australia, said its lawyers had served Chevron with a formal notice of protected industrial action.
The Alliance slammed Chevron's bargaining efforts and said the actions would escalate each week until bargaining claims are agreed to.

"While we don't believe that industrial action is necessary for agreement to be reached, we recognise employees have the right to take protected industrial action," Chevron said in a statement to Reuters.
"We will continue to take steps to maintain safe and reliable operations in the event of disruption at our facilities."
